curam.util.type
Class UniqueID

java.lang.Object
  curam.util.type.UniqueID

public abstract class UniqueID
extends java.lang.Object

UniqueID creates unique 64-bit values for use as application keys. The values returned are unique within a named "key set". An arbitrary number of differently named key sets is supported. The single public method of this class (nextUniqueID) returns the next 64-bit value in sequence from a set.

Unique IDs address the common application requirement for sequences of distinct values for use as keys devoid of "business meaning". One common technical difficulty is that a number of application processes or threads, which are otherwise non-cooperating, must be able to concurrently generate key values without overlap. A general solution is to provide synchronization via a common resource so that a unique id value can be locked, accessed and updated. One easy approach is to use a row of a database table as the common resource, and to use the lock management facilities of a database engine to synchronize access. This unfortunately can result in a serious database hot-spot that can limit throughput of an entire application. If there is a requirement to generate keys in a contiguous sequence, i.e. without any possibility of "holes" in the sequence, then this database hot-spot may well be unavoidable. However, in the absence of such a requirement, the hi-key/lo-key approach to key generation can mitigate any potential performance issues.

The hi-key/lo-key approach makes use of a key server to generate hi-keys . A hi-key represents the most significant portion (in the binary number sense) of a key value, with the low-key part supplied by the client. The client can thus use all of the lo-key values in a hi-key block without accessing the key server again. When the keys in the block are exhausted, the client gets the next hi-key from the server. Synchronization among clients is limited to those times when it is necessary to access the key server. The key server accesses a database table in order to retrieve the next available hi-key. However, this access is not part of any ongoing client transaction, so the key control value on the database is locked only for long enough to retrieve and update a hi-key value. (An obvious implication is that key values can be "lost" if client transactions are rolled back, or if for any reason a client does not use the values from a lo-key block). Another implication is that increasing key values cannot be assumed to correspond to any chronological ordering, since multiple clients can use key values at any time once they have allocated a hi-key via the key server).

Curam uses 8-bit lo-key values, so there are 256 keys in a block. Hi-keys are 56 bits long, so there is to all intents and purposes an inexhaustible supply of hi-key values in each named key set. Each key set is designated as either "human readable" or "non-human-readable". Both types of key sets result in very large ranges of non-overlapping key values.

Human-readable key values start at 1, and are incremented by 1 each time a key is generated (although the caveats about contiguity and ordering noted above still apply).

Non-human-readable (NHR) keys are designed to produce keys which are distributed relatively evenly across the 64-bit key value range, which can be useful for some applications. A non-human-readable key is generated by:

  • generating a variation of a human-readable key whereby its 8-bit lo-key component begins with a value between 0 and 255, and is incremented by an uneven number between 0 and 255 (This means that the 256 possible lo-key values are produced in a non-contiguous sequence E.g: 126, 191, 0, 65, 130...) and
  • reversing the bits of this value.

    This means that for NHR keys, low Unique ID blocks yield high key values and vice versa. So a NHR key between -65535 and +65536 will not be generated for a key set until approximately 2^48 unique keys have been issued for that set, a NHR key between -32765 and +32768 will not be generated for a key set until approximately 2^49 unique keys have been issued for that set, and so on.

    It also supports unique keys to be generated in a system landscape. This is achieved by usage of range aware key server algorithm. Algorithm generates the unique ID based on GroupRange assigned for a given system. The entire 64 bit value is split into uniform blocks of group and range. So in total there are 32768 group, each group has 512 ranges, and each range can have 2^32 key blocks. As it generates unique ID's based on GroupRange assigned to a system, it will be unique in system landscape. Care needs to be taken to assign non-overlapping key ranges to every system in landscape.

    nextUniqueID

    public static long nextUniqueID(java.lang.String keySet)
                         throws AppRuntimeException,
                                DatabaseException,
                                AppException
    Return the next unique id in the specified key set.

    Parameters:
    keySet - The name of the key set from which the key is required.
    Returns:
    The next key in set. This will never be zero.
    Throws:
    AppRuntimeException - RUN_ID_KEY_SET_NOT_FOUND - when the Key Set cannot be found.
    DatabaseException - Standard database exceptions
    AppException - Generic Exception Signature.
